article: I can honestly say it was the best of times and the worst of times. I was joyfully expecting my first child at the same time that my mother was  _  her battle with a brain tumor . For ten years, my fiercely independent and  _  mother had fought, but none of the treatments had been successful.  _  , she never lost her ability to smile. But now, finally, she became totally  _  --unable to speak, walk, eat or dress on her own. As she grew closer and closer to death, my  _  grew closer and closer to life inside me. My biggest  _  was that their lives would never connect. I was sad not only at the  _  loss of my mother, but that she and my baby would never know each other. Her doctor did not  _  any hope; they told us her time was up. We brought Mother  _  to her own bed in her own house. As  _  as I could, I sat beside her and talked to her about the baby moving inside me. On February 3, 1989, at about the same time my labor  _  , Mother opened her eyes. When they told me this at the  _  , I called her home, "Mom, listen. The baby is coming! You're going to have a new grandchild!" "Yes! Yes! I know!" Four beautiful words! The first  _  words she'd spoken in months! When I  called up  again an hour later, the nurse at her house told the  _  message: Mom sat up, smiling, with her oxygen tubes removed. When I brought Jacob home. Mom was sitting in her chair and  _  to welcome him. Tears of joy blocked my vision as I  _  my son in her arms and she clucked at him. They  _  . Then she quietly clipped back into a coma and  passed away  peacefully. Memories of my son's birth will always be bittersweet for me, but it was then that I learned love has the  _  to overcome any worries and any sorrow. And love can last forever.
